text: A sparrow flutters in birdseed on a window sill. More bir crowd a bird feeder that hangs above.
A lone child swings lazily on a swing. Other children tea about in a wild game of chase.

CLOSE on a piece of wood as it is fed through a wood chip A man finishes feeding the log into the chipper. He pause wipe the sweat and grime from his face. He is WALTER, ear forties, features handsome but hardened by time.

Walter is silhouetted by the early morning light. He hold duffel bag in his lap and watches out the bus window. The sun is just rising over the horizon, streaks of pink purple graze the frosted ground. Wilderness gives way to frozen farmland.
Walter stands at a counter, a female officer fingerprints each finger.
Walter and some other men drop the side of the flatbed tr and trees crash to the ground.
The bus pulls away, revealing Walter standing alone on th sidewalk of a dilapidated neighborhood. He holds his duff bag.

The 5 o'clock whistle BLOWS. Workers hustle to get their coats and punch out. Walter stands in line, keeping to himself. As his turn arrives to punch out he receives a r knock by two guys play-fighting behind him. Walter doesn' react, punches out, and exits the door. Vicki, a tough-looking but striking woman, stands in line little further back watching.

A superintendent opens the door to an apartment, then han Walter the keys. Her gaze is cold. Walter closes the door and turns around. He stands in the middle of a prefab/pre-furnished kitchen, living room are Light works its way through the dilapidated blinds.

Walter shakes the boss's hand -- BOB, early thirties, strapping and trim, is the manager of the business. MARY-KAY, the secretary, looks up from her typing and tak Walter in. Bob introduces them. She is in her early forti Walter follows Bob from the office, Mary-Kay watches as t leave.
There is a flash as a camera snaps a photo. Walter is captured in a photograph, standing against a ba blue background.
Walter lifts the blinds. The birds flutter away.
Walter stands under the shower.
Walter, hair wet and clean shaven, tosses back some pills

Tires SCREECH as cars tear out of the driveway. Walter st at a bus stop across the street. As Vicki walks across the lot, a car pulls up next to her men catcall and whistle out the window. Vicki flicks them off. The men burst into hysterics and p out of the lot. She gets in her Jeep and leaves, tearing the bus stop. Walter looks after her then turns his collar up against t chill. It is late winter. The trees are bare -- black silhouettes against the darkening sky. Walter turns towards the shelter for protection from the wind. Filling the kiosk, a clothing advertisement display young girl striking a seductive pose.

CLOSE on a police file. A mug shot reveals Walter, many y younger. Pages are flipped through giving glimpses of new clippings as well as typed documents. Words stand out -- "Convicted, 1st degree --," "3 counts --," "served --." A plain clothes officer closes the folder and looks out h office window where Walter stands being fingerprinted. Th is Sergeant LUCAS, mid-fifties, face creased and greying hair.
Walter watches out the window as farmland gives way to ci Traffic builds, billboards line the highway.
Details of machines cutting the wood.

Walter fills the bird feeder with birdseed. There is the SOUND of children playing, and Walter looks Walter's POV: Across the way, children play outside of th school. Walter watches then closes his window.
Walter exits the police station and crosses the street.

CLOSE on fingers typing on a keyboard. A computer screen shows Walter's image -- the photo just taken of him against the blue background. Words appear ac the screen as they are typed, creating an Internet notification page: Released: 02/25/02 Qualifying Offense(s):____________ We MOVE in on the photo of Walter till it fills the frame FREEZE FRAME. All sound fades out. The title "THE WOODSMAN" fades in.
Walter sits in a small windowless office with his coat st on. He looks at someone off screen.
So. How are you adjusting?
I'm adjusting okay.
And your new apartment?
Apartment's okay.
Are you taking your medication?
It gives me headaches.
But you are taking it?
Yeah.
Across from Walter, sits ROSEN, young, awkward and clearl new to the profession, jotting something down in a notepa
Good. I'll talk to your physician about the headaches. Maybe he can change the prescription.
Walter doesn't say anything. ROSEN (cont'd) And how's your job?
The job's okay.
Do I take "okay" to mean you feel good about working there?
I said the job is okay.
(smiling) That's right, you did. pause) Have you made any friends there?
I'm not running for Mr. Popularity.
(pause) You seem a little hostile today.
That was a joke.
Rosen jots something on his notepad. Walter reaches over taps on the notebook. WALTER (cont'd) It's called sarcasm, Dr. Rosen.
No need to call me doctor. I'm a therapist, not a psychiatrist.
It's all the same.
Rosen looks at Walter for a long moment. Walter avoids hi gaze.
Walter, I'd like you to try something for me.
What?
I'd like you to keep a journal.
A diary?
That's right.
No way.
Why not?
Diaries have sent too many guys to prison.
I don't understand.
Ev-i-dence.
Oh. It never crossed my mind.
Of course.
It was just an idea.
Bad idea.
I thought a journal would encourage you to reflect.
Reflect.
That's right.
You think reflection is good.
It's very good, indeed.
How's that?

By reflection we can derive a deeper meaning from our experience in life. We gain greater understanding about ourselves that can lead to making better choices in our relationships, our careers, and our goals.
Walter looks at him flatly.
You read that in a book.
Rosen blushes.
Try it.
No fucking way.
Then think about it.
Walter is silent.

The sidewalk is crowded with pedestrians. Walter heads towards the pharmacy entrance, but he is abruptly cut off a group of kids zooming by on their scooters and skateboa He pauses for them to pass, watches after them momentaril then proceeds inside.

Walter hands a prescription to a MALE PHARMACIST. The pharmacist looks at the prescription. He glances at Walte then goes over to a FEMALE PHARMACIST working in the back area. She reads the prescription, glances at Walter over her bifocals, then back at the prescription. Walter has not missed any of this.
There a problem?
problem?
A middle-aged shopper talking on her cell phone nearby lo over and pauses in her conversation.
Can you read the prescription?
Yes.
Can you fill the prescription?
Yes.
Then I suggest one of you move your ass, because if I don't get my medication I get extremely violent.
The male pharmacist scrambles to fill the prescription. The shopper gasps. Walter looks at her and smiles. The shopper stuffs her items in her cart and quickly leaves. Walter stifles his grin.
Walter opens the door to his apartment, carrying a grocer bag. As he flips on the lights, a metal object is thrown across the room. He catches it with one hand. It's a can beer. A man laughs.
You still think fast.
Carlos sits at the table with a six-pack. Walter sets the on the table and pops open the can.
Don't need to think fast to handle beer.
ook some talking to convince your super I was a relative.
I told her all my relatives are good-looking.
Carlos laughs.
Jesus Christ, man, it's good to see you!
Carlos stands and they awkwardly embrace. CARLOS (cont'd) You look good, damn good, considering you're an old man now!
Seems like the whole world's gotten younger.
There is silence. Carlos sits back down at the table and opens another beer. Walter starts unpacking the groceries.
You doing okay?
Got a job at old Frank's place. His son runs it now.
Oh man, that kid takes himself real serious.
Yeah, you still with Northland?
(grins) Foreman now.
No shit.
Five years.
Beautiful. How's business?
Booming. Lots of building going on. We can't keep up with all the work. In fact, I just hired a few new guys...
Glancing at Walter, he realizes his blunder. CARLOS (cont'd) Just until we catch up.
There is a brief silence as both men drink. Carlos looks Walter. CARLOS (cont'd) I'll never forget you got me started there.
I just recommended you. You still had to prove yourself.
Carlos gets up and walks over to the window. He gazes outside.
Hey, is that a school?
K through sixth.
Carlos glances at Walter, then back outside.
Living across the street from a grade school. Jesus.
Something wrong with that?
I was just thinking of... the noise.
I like the noise.
Walter walks over to the window. WALTER (cont'd) One hundred and twenty feet.
What?
Law says I can't come within one hundred feet of where children congregate. I figure the distance from my window to the school is one hundred and twenty. Make a bet?
No way, man, you'd rob me blind!
The two men laugh, but the laughter quickly fades. CARLOS (cont'd) But maybe it's not so healthy being so close, you know, to a school.
(heated) You find me a decent place for under three hundred a month in this town, and I'll happily move out of this crap neighborhood.
arlos shrugs and tosses down the rest of his beer.
I should go. Your sister worries, and when she worries she yells.
How is she?
Annette? She's good... tense.
When can I see her?
I'm working on it.
Is it because of Anna?
I don't know. She won't talk about it.
(pause) You're the only one in the family who still talks to me.
I remember when they all referred to me as "the little spic poor Annette married." Except her brother. You treated me with respect. pause) Look, you paid your dues. Your slate is clean now.
How old is Anna?
She'll be twelve next week. We're throwing a big party on Saturday. Wish I could ask you to come...
Only if it's no closer than a hundred feet.
Carlos looks away. WALTER (cont'd) Sorry, bad joke.
They stiffly embrace. Then Carlos exits leaving Walter al

LOSE on a man's feet slowly walking heel to toe. The grou is covered in frost. TILT UP to reveal Walter counting hi footsteps as he walks towards the school across from his apartment building. The schoolyard is empty.
One hundred and ten, one hundred and eleven, one hundred and twelve...
A bird's cry pierces the sky. Walter looks up to see a ha circling above. He watches for a moment then continues walking.
WALTER (cont'd) One hundred and thirteen, one hundred and fourteen, one hundred and fifteen...
He reaches the school entrance and touches it. WALTER (cont'd) One hundred and twenty.
Walter looks at the hawk still circling above and hollers WALTER (cont'd) How about that!?

Slowly the SOUND of children fades in and a red ball boun to Walter's feet. He looks in the direction the ball came from. Nothing is there. Walter looks back down at his feet. The ball is gone. The sound of children fades back away and is replaced by a rhythmic squeak. Walter looks towards the playground wher empty swing sways back and forth in the wind, the chain squeaking in its hinges.
he hawk's cry pierces the silence. Walter looks up to see the hawk being chased by two smaller birds.

There is a tremendous crash as logs are dropped near the chipper. Forklifts move and stack wood. Walter stands at the end of a wood chipper, pushing a lon piece of wood through. Suddenly above the din of machiner there is the sound of raised voices. Walter looks across the way to see Vicki yelling furiousl and smacking a GUY around the head with her work gloves. man cowers, protecting his head from the blows. Some othe men nearby are doubled over in laughter.
GOD DAMN IT! PEDRO! WHAT THE FUCK DO YOU THINK YOU ARE DOING! HOW WOULD YOU FEEL IF SOME FUCKER DID THAT TO YOUR SISTER?! YOU WOULDN'T THINK IT SO FUNNY THEN, WOULD YOU?!
he backs off out of breath. Pedro straightens up, having very hard time keeping a straight face.
he other guys start to applaud. Vicki looks around and storms off, kicking a piece of woo into one of the men, hard. She brushes past Walter on her to the exit. He watches after her.
Vicki sits alone at a table eating a sandwich. She takes large bites and eats fast. Walter approaches carrying a tray of food. He pauses acro from where Vicki sits. icki ignores him.
You okay?
Vicki looks up.
What?
Are you okay?
(pause) Yeah, I'm fucking fantastic.
Walter nods and keeps on walking. Vicki returns to her fo After a moment, she steals a glance up at Walter. Across the way, Mary-Kay watches Walter as he sits down t the table neighboring Vicki's.
Bob sits down across from Mary-Kay with a tray of food an newspaper. He opens the paper and starts to read.
So, what'd he do?
What did who do?
You know, the new guy.
Bob looks across the room at Walter.
Mind your own business, Mary-Kay.
Come on, just tell me what he did.
Bob ignores her and reads the paper. MARY-KAY (cont'd) Drugs, armed robbery, manslaughter, tax evasion -
ob picks up his tray and moves away. Mary-Kay smiles to herself.
Walter sits on the bus. He is squeezed into the window se the bus crowded with commuters and teenagers on their way home from school. He focuses out the window.
Walter sits alone on his couch, watching a baseball game, drinking a beer.
The winning run on base, and a full count on Williams, who's been in a terrible slump. Here's the pitch. Williams swings and misses! The Rangers win, ball game over.

Walter crosses the street outside of his apartment and he towards the bus stop. white Volvo is parked along the road. A MAN sits inside t car looking out towards the school. The engine is off. He in his twenties, good build, nice clothes. Walter looks at the man as he passes by.

he man doesn't notice him, his attention fixed down the street. Walter looks in the direction of his gaze. he schoolyard is quiet except for a couple of students running in. Walter looks back at the man. The man doesn't notice him. Walter hurries to his bus stop.

icki rolls down the passenger side window.
Want a ride?

He gets in. As they pull away, a beat up grey Chevy pulls into the parking lot. Sergeant Lucas gets out of the car, and paus watching after Vicki and Walter. He then turns and heads the office.

Me?

Walter looks out the window. VICKI (cont'd) Here's this nice, hard working guy who suddenly appears out of the blue and rides the bus to and from work. I mean, who rides the bus anymore?
People without cars.
She gives him a look.
Very weird.

icki takes out a cigarette and presses the cigarette ligh in, revealing a tattoo on her wrist of a pair of breasts angel wings. Walter notices the tattoo. Vicki notices Walter notice. S smiles at him. VICKI (cont'd) You're quiet at work.

Your windows face south. Northern light is the purest. But southern light is very good.

Y ou should buy several. I've got shitty light in my place, but my plants don't seem to mind. Light's important, but it's not everything.

VICKI (cont'd) You plan to drink both those beers?
Sorry.

She takes a swig then gazes back out the window. VICKI (cont'd) Is that a school?
K through sixth.

icki wanders through the stark living room space, looking what little there is to look at.
What about bears?

They could eat you.
(laughing) Yeah, they could.
She looks closely at the bus map taped to the wall, the o decoration in the place. She looks at Walter. VICKI (cont'd) I thought you were just shy, but now I think it's something else.

You're damaged.
Walter drinks his beer and sits down on the couch. VICKI (cont'd) Something happened to you.
Yeah?
icki sits next to him.
I'm not easily shocked.
I get that Vimpression.
